results.title: The Explorers [Bill Peach]
results.brief_description: This series follows the trails of the men who opened up the great unknown areas of Australia in the nineteenth century, from the Blue Mountains to the great rivers and deserts.

results.title: The Secret of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Richard Walker and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach recounting the exploration of New South Wale’s river system. In 1828, Charles Sturt, a young English army captain lacking formal qualifications or practical bushman skill, was chosen to explore Australia’s western rivers. Hamilton Hume was appointed second in charge of the expedition and provided the guidance and support that enabled Sturt to unlock the secrets of Australia’s rivers and explode the myth that Australia was a giant basin with its waters draining into an inland sea. His greatest feat was charting the course of the Murray River to the sea. Sturt was an ambitious man who never achieved the high rank that he desired. In an act of ambitious flattery he named the Murray river after the Secretary for the Colonies rather than recognise the discovery made by Hume and Hovell.

results.title: Across the Great Divide
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using historical documents and footage as well as dramatised re-enactments, Bill Peach follows the journey of Evans, Oxley and Cunningham as they cross the Great Dividing Range. He describes the reasons behind their travels, why they chose the route they took, and the ensuing changes to Australian society resulting from their discoveries.

results.title: Prison walls
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using historical documents and footage as well as dramatised re-enactments, Bill Peach describes the epic journey of Blaxland, Wentworth and Lawson as they crossed the Blue Mountains and discovered the lush pastures on the other side. This video also explores the reasons why the expedition was carried out and the impact the discovery had on the growth of the young colony of New South Wales.

results.title: Desert explorers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Bill Peach narrates this informative look at the journeys of the Australian explorers who discovered and conquered the Great Sandy Desert, the Gibson Desert and the Great Victorian Desert - Warburton, Gosse, Forrest and Giles. It has been said that explorers who discover barren places are seen as failures compared to those who discover fertile, productive land. However, from an economic perspective, it is just as important to map the arid areas as the temperate and tropical. Using historical documents and footage as well as dramatised re-enactments, this video traces the trials of the explorers faced with trying to “open up” the continent.

results.title: South to North
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage and documents, Bill Peach narrates this investigation of the race to cross Australia from South to North. The race was driven by colonial rivalry between New South Wales and Victoria, resulting in John McDougall Stuart eventually emerging through the centre of the North Coast at the Gulf of Carpentaria.

results.title: Overland to Port Phillip
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using dramatised re-enactments and historical documents, Bill Peach describes the overland route from Sydney to Melbourne which was originally discovered by Hume and Hovell. This route still survives as the Hume Highway.

results.title: The Pinnacle of fame
results.creator_credit: Richard Walker and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach recounting the efforts of three white Europeans to explore the Gippsland and Australian Alps regions. In 1840, Polish geologist and explorer, Paul Strzelecki joined forces with James Macarthur who was interested in exploring the region for grazing land. Strzelecki is considered the first white man to climb Australia’s highest mountain and reach the Kosciusko plateau. Another Polish explorer, Dr John Lhotsky, travelled through the region six years earlier collecting botanical specimens for European museum, but his efforts were not supported by the New South Wales government and his discoveries remain uncredited. Scottish settler, Angus McMillan, was exploring the area during the same period as Strzelecki but chose to conceal his discoveries until he could claim the land as his own. After persevering through hunger and hardship, Strzelecki stumbled across the ranges that bear his name before reaching Melbourne. Here he published details about his findings and the first detailed map of the region. McMillan was outraged when he read the news which omitted any reference to his exploration, furthermore, the rivers and lakes that he had discovered had been renamed by Strzelecki. Strzelecki argued that credit should be given to the explorer who shared his findings and benefits with the public. McMillan was eventually given credit for his exploration of the region while Lhotsky’s efforts failed.

results.title: Australia Felix
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
A man of many talents, Major Mitchell is credited with discovering an otherwise unknown area of Western Victoria that he referred to as “Australia Felix”, or “Happy Australia”. Over his four costly expeditions, Mitchell was asked to confirm that the Darling River ran into the Murray and to see if there were any undiscovered surrounding areas. Motivated by a passion to disprove Sturt, who had traversed the region before him, Mitchell earned the wrath of Governor Darling and society as a whole thanks to the massacre of blacks at Mt Dispersion. A man of many contrasts, Mitchell was responsible for naming the Grampians, Glenelg River and Discovery Bay. He received a state funeral upon his death.

results.title: East to north
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Presented by Bill Peach, this program uses reenactments to describe the trail taken by the expeditions of Ludwig Leichardt from the eastern settlements in New South Wales north to Port Essington in Northern Australia, documenting the challenges and hardships they faced along the way.
